page.title: 12LOCAL HISTORY Old Oswestry
page.content:
Excavation has been limited so information is also limited as to its date and purpose. However it is thought to date from at least one hundred years B.C. when the local chieftain would have protected his tribe, livestock, and crops from difficult neighbours. Itis believed that the whole earthwork had been completed and abandoned before the Roman Invasion of Great Britain in A.D.43.
To-day it is grassed over and the grass cut at least once a week in summer.Many tree stumps remain from the time of the first world war when Lord Harlech sold off the wood for national needs.In spring it is covered in bluebells.
